postsData.name:
Walker Deibel
Walker Deibel
postsData.content:
Everyone thinks Elon Musk started Tesla.

They're wrong.

Instead, he used a genius acquisition strategy that made him the world's richest man.

Here's how:

In 2003, two engineers started Tesla Motors with a vision to create high-performance electric cars.

But they needed capital.

Enter Elon Musk.

His first move?

Lead the Series A with $6.35M, becoming the largest shareholder and board chairman.

Then he did something brilliant.

During the 2008 financial crisis, with Tesla weeks from bankruptcy, Musk stepped in as CEO and made three game-changing decisions:

‚Ä¢ Laid off 24% of the workforce
‚Ä¢ Invested more of his own money
‚Ä¢ Started building everything in-house

That last move became Tesla's secret weapon.

When the 2021 chip shortage hit, most automakers had to halt production.

Tesla rewrote their software in 2 weeks to support different chips and kept producing while competitors struggled.

The results speak for themselves:

‚Ä¢ Tesla's profit margins: 25.6%
‚Ä¢ Industry average: 17%

But Musk's most brilliant move was turning his personal brand into Tesla's biggest marketing engine.

A single Musk tweet about Tesla correlated with:

‚Ä¢ 1.1% increase in stock price
‚Ä¢ 6.9% increase in trading volume

Cost of this marketing? $0.

Here's the blueprint Elon used:

‚Ä¢ Start as an investor, not founder
‚Ä¢ Focus on the bigger vision
‚Ä¢ Control the entire supply chain
‚Ä¢ Build a powerful personal brand

But here's what most people miss:

The real power move isn't starting from scratch.

It's finding existing businesses with proven track records and taking them to the next level.

After acquiring 8 companies myself, I've learned that the greatest deals are:

‚Ä¢ Profitable but unsexy
‚Ä¢ Primed for growth
‚Ä¢ Owner-operated

The best opportunities are often hidden in plain sight
-

If you enjoyed this post:

Ô∏è Reshare for others who might find it useful
 Follow me, Walker Deibel for more
 Share your thoughts below

comments.commentText:
Walker Deibel they're wrong and so are you, right?

"start as an investor, not a founder"? Really??

In 1995 Musk, his brother Kimbal and Greg Kouri started Global Link Information Network, later renamed Zip2.
Compaq acquired Zip2 for $307 million in cash in February 1999 and Musk received $22 million for his 7 percent share

In March 1999, Musk co-founded, an online financial services and e-mail payment company with $12 million of the money he made from the Compaq acquisition.merged with Confinity which brought PayPal into the company. In 2002, PayPal was acquired by eBay for $1.5 billion in stock, of which Musk, PayPal's largest shareholder with 11.7% of shares, received $176 million.

Musk founded Space X in 2002.

Musk only got involved in Tesla in 2004 when he lead the Series A.

So prior to this involvement in Tesla he had already founded 3 companies with 2 exits under his belt, So kindly elaborate on how Musk started as an investor and not a founder.

Thanks Warren Sterling! Yes, All I'm sayin is that Musk, a revered, successful, and iconoclastic entrepreneur understands that innovation and acquisition are equally important. 

Musk acquired Paypal, Tesla, and X.

But Edwin, you are absolutely correct that he started and sold Zip2. He successfully started from scratch first. It's just not the only path.

After selling Zip2, he bought a McLaren. ; )
Walker Deibel word of the day: ‚Äúiconoclastic‚Äù

We have his #1 right hand man here in Arizona and he started Lucid electric cars in Casa Grande, AZ!

Regardless everyone should have aligned with Toyota Japanese engineers focusing on liquid hydrogen! Cradle to grave analysis of lithium ion batteries is an environmental nightmare compared to liquid hydrogen! From giant holes in the earth heavy diesel powered equipment to make the holes thru energy intensive and expensive recycling of lithium batteries‚Ä¶.liquid hydrogen beats batteries hands down!

Liquid hydrogen is definitely way sexier than batteries on many fronts!

postsData.commentAdded: Innovative strategies like Musks can inspire us all! Its a powerful reminder to think beyond traditional paths to success. üí°

postsData.name:
Manuj Aggarwal
Manuj Aggarwal
postsData.content:
22 Million acres of federal land opened to power AI's future

The US government is now offering federal lands for building AI data centers powered by clean energy like wind and solar.

Here‚Äôs why this matters:

 AI needs LOTS of energy. Think of data centers as the ‚Äúbrains‚Äù running AI. They need tons of power to function. Instead of using dirty fuels, these centers will now tap into renewable energy.

 Clean energy, cleaner planet. By using solar and wind farms, this plan helps fight climate change while supporting cutting-edge tech.

 Innovation meets sustainability. This isn‚Äôt just about tech, it‚Äôs about creating jobs, driving the economy, and building a greener future for everyone.

The idea is simple: Support the growing tech world while protecting the planet.

It‚Äôs exciting to see how smart planning can lead to big changes, don‚Äôt you think?

Let‚Äôs keep an eye on how this shapes our world.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! This initiative is a game-changer for tech and sustainability. Excited to see how it drives innovation and job growth! üå±üí°

postsData.name:
ü¶æJepson Taylor
ü¶æJepson Taylor
postsData.content: Word of warning: DeepSeek AI is really exciting. Everyone should be trying it, but anything you put in consider it now in the open domain. Anthropic and OpenAI have protections they have refined through experience if you accidentally put in an API key etc... I think those safety features you take for granted will not be as robust yet. So assume anything you are sending in could be made freely available to your biggest competitor or a hacker. Better yet, host your own instance. Doesn't mean you shouldn't use it, just be mindful that the safety walls you take for granted are most likely down if you don't control the server. Food for bot.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Its essential to balance innovation with caution. Hosting your own instance could be a game changer for data security. üåêüîí

postsData.name:
‚≠êÔ∏èTiffany Slowinski‚≠êÔ∏è
‚≠êÔ∏èTiffany Slowinski‚≠êÔ∏è
postsData.content:
Holy smokes! These young entrepreneurs blew me away.

Last week EO New Jersey asked me to be a judge at GSEA Business Plan Competition. Judging this competition was HARD. These students‚Äîat just 19-21 years old‚Äîare doing much more than I was at that age (and honestly, maybe more than I did last year). They weren‚Äôt just pitching ideas; they were running legitimate businesses, taking risks, and proving why the future of entrepreneurship is in good hands.

We judged them based on EO‚Äôs Core Values, and they did not disappoint:

 Trust and Respect‚Äì Treating each member with equality and valuing diverse perspectives.
 Thirst for Learning ‚Äì A constant curiosity to acquire new knowledge and grow.
 Think Big, Be Bold ‚Äì Embracing innovation and taking calculated risks to make a significant impact.
 Together We Grow ‚Äì Commitment to supporting each other's success and well-being.

Every single competitor brought their A-game, but our winners stood out:

1st Place:, Rutgers Honors College student and CEO of, a dorm & apartment security system that fits right over the door handle. Smart, inexpensive, and something I‚Äôll absolutely be buying for my daughters when they head to college! Anjo‚Äôs already built an executive team, launched multiple non-profits, and is heading to Puerto Vallarta to compete at the next level!

2nd Place:, Rowan University student and Founder of‚Äîa sustainable, boutique makeup brand with a mission to empower through representation.

 The Other Competitors Were Just as Impressive:

Circlez ‚Äì: A project management platform for SME manufacturers, already gaining traction.

Electrix Vintage ‚Äì Daniel Thomas: A sustainable second-hand fashion business.

Calorie Dense Nutrition ‚Äì: A high-protein health bar‚Äîfree of harmful additives and surprisingly delicious!

Reef ‚Äì Mark Schmidt: A platform for verifying content authenticity in an age of misinformation.

This event reminded me that I love working with students (former guidance counselor here ). These students aren‚Äôt just building businesses‚Äîthey‚Äôre building the future. And when they‚Äôre ready to grow their teams, I‚Äôll be there to support them.

If you had to pick one EO core value that resonates with you most, which would it be? Drop a comment!

comments.commentText: The level of innovation and ambition displayed by these young entrepreneurs is truly impressive. For me, the core value of "Thirst for Learning" stands out. Continuous curiosity is essential; without it, we risk stagnation in both personal and professional growth. Excited to see how these future leaders will shape the business landscape!

postsData.commentAdded: Incredible to see such innovation and drive from the next generation! üåü Think Big, Be Bold truly resonates with me. Excited for their futures!

The era of 
hashtag
#PredictiveSecurity is on us,

Definitely an age for board and CxO to refine their tooling / team skills toward forecasting future.

is here to help :)

postsData.content: I view jargon more like a crutch for B2B marketers: it's what they say when they don't know what to say. What's your take?

Adam Boggs

postsData.content:
Why We Need Smart Meetings (Not Fewer) 
I‚Äôve spent 13+ years designing workshops for companies like Google and Salesforce, and here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned: The problem isn‚Äôt too many meetings‚Äîit‚Äôs poorly designed ones.
Most meetings still rely on outdated tools (like chaotic whiteboards or rigid agendas) that kill creativity. That‚Äôs why we built, an AI-powered platform that helps teams run smarter meetings‚Äîfocused on real-time engagement, strategic alignment, and outcomes that stick.
In my latest blog, I break down how blending creativity (‚Äúdivergent thinking‚Äù) with structure can transform meetings from time-wasters into innovation engines. Spoiler: It‚Äôs not about cutting meetings. It‚Äôs about making them matter.
 Read it here: Why We Need Smart Meetings

P.S. Follow me for more on facilitation, AI-driven collaboration, and leading teams that thrive in ambiguity.

comments.commentText: Adam, I've sat through my fair share of dumb meetings. It's pretty liberating to call them dumb. Also, I love your take on AI meeting notetakers‚Äîa transcript isn‚Äôt a roadmap, and it certainly doesn‚Äôt make a meeting smarter.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! It‚Äôs all about transforming the meeting culture. Excited to check out your insights on blending creativity with structure!

postsData.name:
Bidisha Dutta
Bidisha Dutta
postsData.content:
When I committed to LinkedIn, I had no idea what to expect.

(I got serious after quitting LinkedIn 4 times!)

In just 6 months, here‚Äôs what happened:

- My network grew.
- My visibility boosted.
- I got to learn from the industry biggies.
- Strangers started appreciating my work.
- I went from "no one" to "someone" who matters.
- I connected with incredible founders and coaches.

What did you do,?

I achieved all of these through:

-Consistency
-Authenticity
-Showing up even when it felt scary.
-Sharing chunks of my life that my audience wanted to read.

LinkedIn isn‚Äôt just a platform. It‚Äôs an opportunity.
It's not just about professionalism. It's about personal touch.
It's not just numbers and statistics. It's about human stories.

Are you making the most of it?

P.S. Are you Team Inbound or Team Outbound?
I am a blend of both!

comments.commentText:
Can you guess the name of this dish? 
Hint: It's a popular Rajasthani delicacy!

I got the opportunity to learn from the storyteller queen Rose M. yesterday. And this was possible because I chose to be on LinkedIn, showed up daily despite having a hectic schedule, and consistently engaged with Rose as well as other creators whom I consider to be my LinkedIn family.

We talked about LinkedIn and life, content and clients, dreams and difficulties. And being an old soul, I grabbed my diary and made lots of notes as Rose was sharing some amazing value nuggets.

Why am I sharing this with you all? Because we all need some help at times. Seeking help doesn't make you small. It may get tiring as you keep figuring it out yourself. Do seek out help from someone you can trust! For me, that person is Rose.

I got your back, Bidisha Dutta 

Keep going

postsData.commentAdded: Inspiring journey! Your commitment shows the true power of authenticity and connection on LinkedIn. Excited to see where you go next!

postsData.name:
Ian Koniak
Ian Koniak
postsData.content:
I just had a coaching client finish #1 on his team and sell over 300% of quota! It was the best year of his career. How do you think his company rewarded him?
They just distributed 2025 quotas, and his new quota is 4x anybody else's on the same team.

How is that fair and equitable?

How is that motivating?

When companies do this, it sends a clear message: we don't value you or care about you as a person.

Unfortunately I've seen this happen too many times.

Top reps have incredible years, and get "rewarded" by having their quotas doubled or tripled the next year.

Because greedy leaders think their top reps are getting paid too much and don't want to see it happen again.

To these companies I say this: good riddance.

Your best sellers should go elsewhere...and they will.

If a company messes with your comp or quota to pay you less, it's time to take your talents elsewhere.

Know your worth and go work for a company that values and pays you for what you bring to the table.

Life is too short to take a 50% pay cut as a reward for pouring your blood, sweat, and tears into a record-breaking year, only to get penalized for it.

comments.commentText: Again, you are basing quota off of rep attainment. It doesn't scale. It's also fundamentally the definition of insanity. There are too many proof points that this is not the way to forecast rep productivity. Candidly, it's lazy. Ontheme of the day, do better.
Lucas Wilson Yes sir - do better!

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Companies should celebrate top talent, not penalize them. Knowing your worth is crucial‚Äîfind an employer that truly values you!

postsData.name:
Khwaja Shaik
Khwaja Shaik
postsData.content:
DeepSeek's Disruption & Open-Source GenAI: A Critical Board Perspective

The recent DeepSeek breakthrough, combined with the broader rise of open-source GenAI, is reshaping the strategic landscape in ways that demand immediate board attention. As a director deeply engaged in tech governance, I'm seeing seismic shifts that boards must address:

Strategic Inflection Points:
1. DeepSeek has demonstrated that competitive AI performance is achievable without cutting-edge chips‚Äîchallenging core assumptions about AI infrastructure investments
2. Open-source GenAI models are enabling self-hosted solutions that address critical IP protection and data security concerns
3. We're witnessing a democratization of AI innovation where smaller, specialized models achieve comparable results at fraction of the cost

Critical Board Oversight Areas:

Risk & Governance:
‚Ä¢ Export controls may not provide the technological moat previously assumed
‚Ä¢ Need for robust governance frameworks for open-source AI adoption
‚Ä¢ Clear compliance protocols for licensing and security measures
‚Ä¢ Infrastructure investment strategies need reassessment

Competitive Strategy:
‚Ä¢ Speed to market vs. security trade-offs
‚Ä¢ Developer experience and talent retention
‚Ä¢ Strategic partnerships vs. in-house development
‚Ä¢ Data sovereignty and IP protection

The $1 trillion market reaction to DeepSeek shows the stakes. But the real story isn't market volatility‚Äîit's about long-term value creation in an environment where technological advantages can shift rapidly.

Action Items for Boards:
1. Dedicate specific board time to examine AI governance frameworks
2. Request comprehensive scenario planning from management
3. Review risk frameworks to include emerging AI competitors
4. Assess infrastructure investment strategies against new realities

The message is clear: This isn't just a tech trend‚Äîit's a strategic imperative that demands sophisticated board oversight. The companies that get this right will create sustainable competitive advantages; those that don't risk being left behind.

What's your board's approach to balancing AI innovation with proper governance? How are you thinking about the implications of open-source AI for your competitive strategy?

comments.commentText: Brilliant analysis on the DeepSeek disruption! As a fellow board member, I completely agree - the democratization of AI through open-source models is reshaping our strategic playbook. We're focusing heavily on agile governance frameworks while accelerating our open-source AI initiatives. The opportunities are simply incredible.
Manuj Aggarwal, Well said. You are the champion of open source AI who sees tremendous value for both short and long terms. Strategic Agility is the key.

postsData.commentAdded: Insightful post! Boards must prioritize AI governance now more than ever to harness innovation while mitigating risks effectively. Great points!

postsData.name:
Stephen Baines
Stephen Baines
postsData.content:
Plot twist: Your talent isn't the problem...

It's the 6-word lie you tell yourself daily: 

"I'm not good enough for this."

Here's the psychological truth most won't tell you... That voice is LYING!

Today, I‚Äôm bringing you's visual brilliance, supported by
my 5 mindset shifts to silence self-doubt and unlock untapped growth:

 Progress > Perfection
‚Ü≥ Small wins are compound interest. Today‚Äôs 1% is tomorrow‚Äôs breakthrough
‚Ü≥ Perfection isn‚Äôt the goal. Progress is
‚Ü≥ Track your wins, no matter how small

 "I can't" ‚Üí "I can't YET‚Äù
‚Ü≥ The one word that changes everything
‚Ü≥ Every limit is just a temporary state
‚Ü≥ Every "no" is just a "not yet"

Ô∏è Effort Trumps Talent
‚Ü≥ Natural talent has a ceiling
‚Ü≥ Effort breaks through it
‚Ü≥ Consistency beats intensity every time

 Failures = Future Wins
‚Ü≥ Every ‚Äúfailure‚Äù is market research in disguise
‚Ü≥ Every setback has a lesson embedded within
‚Ü≥ It‚Äôs not "Why me?". It's "What‚Äôs next?‚Äù

Ô∏è Comfort Zones Kill Growth
‚Ü≥ The magic is always just outside your comfort zone.
‚Ü≥ Discomfort = Development
‚Ü≥ Embrace the uncertainty as that‚Äôs where the magic happens

 The reality check:

Your mindset isn't hard-wired. It's a CHOICE

Every morning, you choose:
‚Üí Comfort or growth
‚Üí Excuses or results
‚Üí Fear-fueled or future-focused

The potential is there

The only permission you need is yours

 Big Q: Which mindset shift are you embracing today?

Ô∏è Repost to help another leader to grow
 Followfor more leadership, growth and mindset content

comments.commentText: Self-doubt is a thief that steals opportunities before they even have a chance to exist. The truth is, talent will only take you so far. It‚Äôs mindset, effort, and resilience that determine how far you actually go.

postsData.commentAdded: Powerful insights! Embracing I cant YET has transformed my approach‚Äîthank you for highlighting the power of mindset shifts! üöÄ #GrowthMindset
